docs.snippet: ''THE Rockies may crumble, Gilbraltar may tumble, they're only made of clay,'' goes the lyric of George and Ira Gershwin's final collaboration, ''Our Love Is Here to Stay.'' And in New York these days, the music of the Gershwins looks to be as dur...
docs.lead_paragraph: ''THE Rockies may crumble, Gilbraltar may tumble, they're only made of clay,'' goes the lyric of George and Ira Gershwin's final collaboration, ''Our Love Is Here to Stay.'' And in New York these days, the music of the Gershwins looks to be as durable as the love that outlasts geologic wonders. At the Ballroom on West 28th Street, you can hear, thanks to the technological marvel known as the reproducing piano, the composer himself accompanying the renowned 71-year-old mouth-organist Larry Adler through ''Rhapsody in Blue.'' Uptown in the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel, Michael Feinstein, the young singer and pianist who spent six years cataloguing Ira Gershwin's records and sheet music, has begun an open-ended engagement that will include a hefty selection of Gershwin tunes. Mr. Feinstein's New York debut follows appearances in Los Angeles, San Francisco and Houston.

headline.main: IT'S VERY CLEAR, THE GERSHWINS ARE HERE TO STAY

docs.snippet: Chancellor Helmut Kohl invoked West Germany's national interests and the lives of German expatriates today as he explained his Government's refusal to follow the United States in imposing economic sanctions on Libya.   ''I can well understand the ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Chancellor Helmut Kohl invoked West Germany's national interests and the lives of German expatriates today as he explained his Government's refusal to follow the United States in imposing economic sanctions on Libya. ''I can well understand the reaction of the Americans, but I ask them to understand that we have 1,500 Germans there,'' Mr. Kohl said at a news conference, referring to his countrymen who work in the North African nation. ''When I became Chancellor I took an oath swearing to defend the interests of the German people,'' he said. ''It is obvious that I must put German interests first, and when I do it can produce a difference of opinion'' with the United States, he added.

headline.main: KOHL EXPLAINS REFUSAL TO MOVE AGAINST LIBYA

byline.original: By JAMES M. MARKHAM, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: Interior Minister Oscar Luigi Scalfaro of Italy with his Austrian counterpart, Karl Blecha, left, yesterday in Vienna. They said their countries would sign an accord for cooperation in the fight against terrorism. The two countries were the scenes...
docs.lead_paragraph: Interior Minister Oscar Luigi Scalfaro of Italy with his Austrian counterpart, Karl Blecha, left, yesterday in Vienna. They said their countries would sign an accord for cooperation in the fight against terrorism. The two countries were the scenes of twin airport terrorist attacks two weeks ago. (Agence-France/Presse)

docs.snippet: One of the most likable things about Mark Morris as a choreographer is the way he romps through styles and forms like a frisky puppy.   Since he began making dances in 1980, he has choreographed to Brahms, Vivaldi, rock, gospel songs and tradition...
docs.lead_paragraph: One of the most likable things about Mark Morris as a choreographer is the way he romps through styles and forms like a frisky puppy. Since he began making dances in 1980, he has choreographed to Brahms, Vivaldi, rock, gospel songs and traditional Tahitian and Indian music, and his themes have ranged from the intoxication of love to the social significance of wrestling. His refusal to limit himself to any single way of moving should gladden dancegoers who hate to see young choreographers fall into esthetic ruts. Mr. Morris has lots of ideas, including ideas about structure, and he enjoys trying out different ways of putting dances together. Take ''I Love You Dearly,'' which was offered during the Mark Morris Dance Group's recent season at the Bessie Schonberg Theater. This solo for Guillermo Resto, to a suite of Rumanian folk songs, made one recall that Mr. Morris once performed with a Balkan folk dance group. In fact, the suite's first dance was like a folk song made visible. At the beginning of each new stanza of the accompanying song, Mr. Resto would pause in a corner of the stage. Thus the dance, like the music, was stanzaic in structure.

headline.main: HOW NOT TO GET TRAPPED IN A CHOREOGRAPHIC RUT

docs.snippet: The DC-3 aircraft that crashed and killed Ricky Nelson and six other people had engine trouble before its last flight, and one member of the singer's band had talked of quitting because he did not trust the plane, friends and relatives said today....
docs.lead_paragraph: The DC-3 aircraft that crashed and killed Ricky Nelson and six other people had engine trouble before its last flight, and one member of the singer's band had talked of quitting because he did not trust the plane, friends and relatives said today. Mr. Nelson, 45 years old, who became known to millions of Americans as a child on his family's television series, ''The Adventures of Ozzie and Harriet,'' was flying with his fiancee and five members of his band from Alabama to Dallas for a New Year's Eve concert when the plane crashed near this town just south of the Oklahoma border. The pilot and co-pilot survived and were hospitalized with burns. The pilot, Brad Rank, 34, was in fair condition and the co-pilot, Kenneth Ferguson, 40, was in critical condition.

headline.main: MEMBER OF RICKY NELSON'S BAND WAS SET TO QUIT BECAUSE OF PLANE
